Ko te kōutu e wahi Tautarangimārie. Ko te kōutu e wahi Okiokinga. Ko te kōutu e wahi mo te iwi. Naumai, haramai, whakatau mai rā.  To all the people of the four winds, we extend our warmest welcome. The people of Ngāti Koroki, Kahukura and Ngāti Hauā pay our acknowledgements to our many departed ancestors. Welcome to Te Kootū, where, in the words of Kingi Tāwhiao, stated, Cambridge is my washbowl of sorrows. Te Kootū is a place of peace. Te Kootū is a place of relaxation. Te Kootū is a place for all people.  enter, enjoy and be welcome. I'd like to express my gratitude to the mayor and the council for hearing our presentation for this concept plan. You will be supplied with a fair bit of supporting documentation on this presentation. My intention is not to give you the entire presentation before you, but to give our perspective as mana whenua to the concept plan for Lake Te Kootu.  The Eastern Mana Whenua Gateway that is envisaged to be a waharoa. A waharoa is an entrance gateway that can show the cultural influence of the iwi associated with Lake Te Kootu. It enables the stories of mana whenua to be told, but also provides a cultural symbolism to be told. The Marahupara Playground and Meeting Place. A marahupara is a series of  interconnecting logs to be climbed on, walked along, and used by all life forms. Fallen trees and native wetlands and forests were a haven for play throughout the centuries. They were used as footpaths, access ways, climbed over, used in play as props for forts, even utilized as meeting places for people of all ages. A natural playground, marahupara,  gives a more cultural perspective to play. It encourages natural confidence building in play. The concept plan intended to focus recommendations on options that provide the most sustainable outcomes over both short and long term. As for the lake itself, water quality is an important aspect. The water quality of Lake Te Kootu has been degraded significantly by the inputs from catchments surrounding it.  The report's recommendations focus on options providing the most sustainable outcomes over both a short and long-term period, with emphasis on solutions that act to reduce long-term contaminant build-ups and inputs into the lake. Without improvement of stormwater treatment in the Lake England Reserve, options in isolation are unlikely to achieve measurable improvements to water quality.  Therefore, stormwater management should adopt a systems approach with treatment options implemented when and where possible as part of new capsule works programs or as part of general operational and maintenance work.  undertaking stormwater improvement work as add-ons, such as as part of our wider projects, such as roading, plumbing or stormwater system upgrades is an option that other local authorities are starting to consider more widely. Critical factors for improving water quality of Lake Te Kootu is treatment of the stormwater before it gets to the lake.  so that any other flow of water going out to the Awa Waikato is in the best condition as possible. Options are limited at the stormwater inflow points into the lake due to the restricted access and narrow space around the lake perimeter. However, the space within the lake offers an opportunity to implement  water quality treatment measures which can be closely aligned to landscape and amenity objectives for lakes to call to, such as lake edge plantings, lake outpour planting and western wetland. You'll see that western wetland is being a little bit hard to describe on the left hand side of that particular map that you're looking at at the moment.  Wetlands and edge plantings have been planned to cool any stormwater ingress into the lake, because obviously we know that during the summer months, any water coming into the lake can sometimes be quite a temperature. The wetland also helps to filter out many contaminants, in addition to lowering the temperature of the stormwater from the hot roads and surrounding areas.  and capture sediment in a natural, passive, low-maintenance ecological system. Plantings to encourage native wildlife, providing marakai for native birds as in food resources, kainga kōhanga for bats and native species for nesting, wetland plantings to improve water quality and water life, thereby enhancing biodiversity.  This plan is in collaboration with experts and interested parties from the council staff, the community and mana whenua. As such, the plan aims to strengthen the connections between Te Kootu, the Cambridge community, mana whenua and all visitors.  Tēnā koutou, tēnā koutou katoa. E rangiraua ki a koutou āku whānau e hui hui mai nei wāngi nui a tātou. Ki te mea Jim, ki tō tātou tūrū, Councillor Susan O'Regan. He mihi nui tēnei ki a koutou katoa. So just on this slide, I'm going to take the opportunity to do a little theme setting around who Ngati Koroki Kahukura  is. Whilst the maunga has a very rich human history, the Crown has acknowledged in our settlement that Ngāti Koroki Kahukura are the iwi with dominant mana whenua interests, rights and interests in respect of the maunga. And we fought for that in our treaty settlement and it's actually something that we live. It's not just words on a settlement page.  We continue to be a strong supporter of the restoration project on the mountain. We've raised, as an iwi, close to a million dollars, actually, through our external relationships to assist with the ongoing work of the MEIT project. We underwrote Sirocco's very first visit, which turned out to be a huge success. One of our tribal members has gifted land to the project, which has become known as the Tautari Wetland.  We have a lot of lands, privately owned lands, within the Maunga project. We have been integral in creating and maintaining inter-iwi relationships with other iwi who give species to the project, which has been critical to the project's success. And of course, we still have the participation of the current co-chair, Poto Davies, and many other  members and representatives over the years. So just in terms of the Treaty Settlement, we reached our own Treaty Settlement on behalf of Ngāti Koroki-Kahukura in 2012 with the Crown. And the legislation that completed the settlement was passed in 2014. And there are a number of references to that legislation in the draft plan.  In addition to our support that I referred to just earlier, as part of our settlement we also sought an advance of funds from the Treaty Settlement so that we could contribute one third of the purchase price of the Visitor Centre, Manutioriori, when the opportunity arose to purchase that property.  We have made a commitment to continue working with MEIT and the council to protect the integrity and security of the fence and achieved some money through our settlement to assist with that.  And another key feature of the settlement is that it establishes Te Hapori o Maungatautari, which in a nutshell is the symbolic owner of the reserve land in Maungatautari and replaced Queen Elizabeth II on the title as the owner.  Te Hāpori o Maungatautari includes Ngāti Koroki-Kahukura as well as Ngāti Hauā, Waikato-Tainui, Raukawa and the community of Maungatautari represented by Waipāmea. Although the Crown retains the rights and responsibilities of the holder of the fee simple estate in the reserve lands, there may be times when a transaction needs to occur involving Te Hāpori o Maungatautari  And if that happens, then a decision is valid if the mayor and three of the iwi named in the settlement agree. I just want to point out here that this was not the redress of choice for Ngāti Koroki-Kahukura. We preferred that our reserve lands be returned to us and vested in an ancestor of Ngāti Koroki-Kahukura or that the mountain be afforded its own legal personality. But that was, those options were declined.  by the Crown. Te Hāpori o Maungatautari is not a legal entity, it's not a co-governance body either. The governance and management arrangements of the maunga remain unaffected by the settlement. The settlement triggered a review of the reserve management plan that was to be conducted by ourselves, Ngāti Koroki Kahukura and the Waipaha District Council and as Anna has said, we created  or formed a reference group to assist in that process and over the many years that this process has been going on we've seen a rotation of staff and a number of different people helping on behalf of the council so I acknowledge Anna's acknowledgement of the patience of Ngati Koroki Kahukura in going through this process  Why did we think that our settlement trigger a review of the plan? We felt that a review would provide an opportunity for a clearer and more forward-thinking reserve management plan.
